p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Eighteenth Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE Nebraska Home for Dependent Children LINCOLN. NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium Ending November 30, 1918

564 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF NEBRASKA HOME FOR DEPENDENT CHILDREN. LINCOLN, NEBRASKA OFFICERS Amy V. Stevens Superintendent and State Agent B. A. Finki.e Physician Blanche M. Him Secretary and Bookkeeper Minnie McMahox Matron EMPLOYEES Mollie Oldberg Day Baby Nurse Rebecca Bkeidexstein Night Baby Nurse Emma K. Graves General Nurse Mart E. Hoixahax Girls' Governess Anna Franxis Boys' Governess Bbidget Kilcoy.xe Dining-room Girl Liljje McGoogan Seamstress

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 565 NEBRASKA HOME FOR DEPENDENT CHILDREN, LINCOLN, NEBRASKA To hi* Excellency, Honorable Keith "Seville, Governor, and to the Honorable Members of the Board of Commix - mixxionerx of State Institutions, Henry denies, Silas A. Ifoleomb, and Eugene 0. Mayfield. Gentlemen: I hereby submit to you the eighteenth biennial report of the Nebraska Home for Dependent Children, covering the period from December 1, 1916, to November 30, 1918. EXECUTIVE AND STAFF CHANGES Several changes have taken place during the past biennium. Miss Etta Caton, who had served as State Agent since September, 1909, was relieved from duty in April, 1917. She was succeeded on May 1, 1917, by Dr. W. H. Crutcher, who was appointed Superintendent of the Orthopedic Hospital and Nebraska Home for Dependent Children. Mrs. Carrie M. Benbrook, matron of the Ortho - pedic Hospital, was asked to serve as matron of this in - stitution also. On May 1, 1917, the writer, who had assisted Miss Caton since September, 1909, was appointed State Agent and was to assume the responsibility of receiving and plac - ing all children. Dr. W. H. Crutcher found the work of superintending both institutions too heavy. He retired as superintendent of the "Home" June 1, 1918, but attended to the physical needs of the children until September 20, 1918, when Dr. B. A. Finkle was appointed. The vacancy created by the resignation of Dr. W. H. Crutcher was filled on June 1, 1918, by Miss Amy V. Stevens. Aside from the changes made in the executive head of our institution we have had five different matrons and three different secretaries during the biennium. These changes have left their effect upon the work.

566 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF OUR NEW HOME Iii 1914 the Legislature appropriated $27,500.00 for the construction and furnishing of a new building near the Orthopedic Hospital with the view of bringing together all the dependent children who for the past five years had been boarded in private residences throughout Lincoln and its suburbs. The building was completed in February, 1917. However, it was not completely furnished so that it was impossible to gather the children in at once. By May 1st all had been removed from their boarding homes and pro - vided for in the institution. The building is a reinforced concrete, fire proof struc - ture 69x85 feet. It consists of four floors occupied as fol - lows: 1st floor, serving kitchen, children's dining room, boys' and girls' play rooms, dry storage rooms; 2nd floor, girls' dormitory with dressing room, bath and toilet and girls' governess room adjoining, general reception room, em - ployees' and officers' dining room, matron's office and super - intendent's offices and apartments; 3rd floor, boys' dormi - tory upon the same plan as the girls', guest rooms, officers' apartments, nursery, sun parlor and diet kitchen; 4th floor, sewing room, general store room and employees' rooms. There is a large porch at the front of the building and two at the rear. There is no kitchen at the Nebraska Home for De - pendent Children. Owing to the close proximity of the Orthopedic Hospital, food is prepared and cooked in their kitchen. At the time our building was constructed it was considered more economical to have the one kitchen supply food for both institutions and to have an underground tunnel connecting the two institutions. The tunnel has not been built so the food is transferred in a cart. The arrange - ment has not proven very satisfactory as it is impossible to get the food over in good condition in cold and stormy weather. The Orthopedic Hospital supplies our building with heat and also does our laundry work. All our sick people are cared for in their hospital. The building is lighted by electricity supplied by the State Penitentiary.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 567 PURPOSE OF THE INSTITUTION The purpose of the institution is to care for all children under sixteen years of age, who are dependent for support, neglected, abandoned or ill-treated, who have been perma - nently committed to its care by any juvenile court, district or county court acting under the juvenile court law. The institution also provides for the care of children who are received as temporary wards. The Board has the power at its discretion to receive such children upon the payment of their board and care from their legal guardian or in case the legal guardian is unable to pay the county commissioners assume the responsibility of the child's main - tenance. Such children are not subject to adoption but are kept in the institution until some other arrangement is made for their care. During the biennium we have received $2439.82 for the board and care of temporary wards. We have found it much more convenient to care for the children in the institution and have been able to place them out in permanent family homes more readily. It also gives us the opportunity of making a more careful study of the child, to build him up physically, socially and morally. The child is now under our immediate supervision so that we learn to know the individual child better, hence, can prepare him more quickly for his permanent home. In order to do good child placing it is necessary to know the child as well as the home in which he is to be placed. EDUCATIONAL AND RELIGIOUS TRAINING The children while living in the institution attend a public school which is about three blocks distant. We consider it much better for the child to attend the public school. He takes more interest in his work and has the opportunity of meeting and associating with other children. Miss Lena Merrill, principal of the Saratoga school, where our children attend, and her corps of teachers have been most faithful in co-operating with us in the teaching and training of our children. On account of the movement of our population and the contagious diseases in the insti-

568 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF tution, the attendance at school is necessarily quite irreg - ular. The children also go outside of the institution to attend Sunday school and church. ENTERTAINMENT Diversions are provided for the children in various ways. Our children have attended the state fair each year and were taken to the two best circuses which came to town during the biennium. Occasional entertainments are given by visitors and a program in which each child takes part is given upon special holidays, such as Christmas, Thanks - giving, Hallowe'en and the Fourth of July. IMPROVEMENTS Even though our building is new it has been necessary to have a great deal of work done upon it. Several clothes closets and medicine chests have been built. Tiling has been laid under ground from all drains and connected with the common sewer. The grounds have been graded and enclosed with heavy steel wire fencing. Cement walks were laid to the front, side and rear of the building. There has also been a large cement floor laid underneath the rear porch which has added greatly to the sanitary condition of the grounds. Three drinking fountains have been installed and the drinking cup abolished. A new play ground outfit consist - ing of see-saw, slide and swings made of heavy steel piping has been installed upon the play ground. This was pur - chased with the gift of $100.00 from Elsie Murphy, a good friend of the children. New trapeze and turning poles have been purchased and will be installed in the boys' play room. The interior of the building, aside from a few rooms on the fourth floor, has been painted and most of the wood work done over. The building at present is in good condition and it is our thought to keep it so.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 569 PLACING OF CHILDREN The state agent, who at the present time is superintend - ent of the Home," is authorized to consent to the adoption of any child who has been committed to the state as a permanent ward. These children are placed in suitable family homes as soon as possible after they are received into the institution. If all the children received were normal it would be quite an easy matter to place them. We have a few children who really belong in an institution. By this I mean the child who is slow mentally, who lacks the ability to distinguish right from wrong. He is not feeble-minded nor is he delinquent, but he does not fit into the family home, as he is unable to withstand temptation and, if placed, is sure to be returned within a short time. We find that such children are especially gifted in music and art and many of them are natural mechanics. If they could be given special instruction along such lines they would no doubt be artists in their profession. During the biennium we have placed 382 children and out of this number 277 have kept their home. There have been 100 adoptions completed and 11 contracts signed. Twenty children were returned to their parents or friends, 20 transferred to other institutions, 21 died, 29 reached their majority and 2 married before they reached their majority. INVESTIGATION OF HOMES A careful investigation is made of a home before a child is placed. Care is also exercised by the institution to place the right child in the right home. All children are placed on four months trial, after which time if every - thing is satisfactory some permanent arrangement is made for the child to remain in the home. The younger children are always adopted but the older ones are simply taken into the home as a member of the family and we expec* them to be treated as such.

THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF During the biennium we have had 731 applications to take children. Of this number 104 were withdrawn, 99 were rejected. We investigated 382 homes into which chil - dren were placed. FIELD WORK Our field work has been somewhat handicapped on account of not having a worker in the field all the time. However, we have all worked hard and given as much time and thought to the field work as possible. It is quite important that we have a good, conscientious worker in the field all the time. I recommend that an appropriation be made for the salary of a worker who can spend as much time as needed in the field. It is too much for one person to assume the responsibility of the institution and field work alone. During the biennium we have visited 374 homes into which children have been placed. Paid 472 visits to chil - dren and called upon 154 while they were in attendance at school. PLANS FOR THE FUTURE It is very necessary that we have an isolation cottage erected close to the "Home" to be used as a receiving cottage for the children when admitted. We receive chil - dren from all over the state and many of them have been exposed to some contagious disease and no matter how cautious we are in receiving them and disinfecting their clothing we will have more or less of the exanthematous diseases. In order to build an isolation cottage we must have more ground. I would recommend that the two lots just north of the "Home" be purchased and the cottage erected. If the Orthopedic Hospital is to supply our institution with food, we should have an underground tunnel con - necting the two institutions. However, we are asking for an appropriation of $1000.00 to build and equip a new kitchen at our institution. We feel that it would be much more satisfactory to have our cooking done in our own

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 571 institution as the food could be served while hot and would be much more wholesome. Below is a brief and itemized survey of appropriations required for the biennium beginning April 1, 1919, and ending March 31, 1921. For salaries and wages $15,000.00 $63,100.00 CONCLUSION I desire at this time to give full credit to my faithful officers and employees who have ably and conscientiously assisted me in the care and training of the children en - trusted to our care. Dr. A. B. Finkle, our physician, has given most excel - lent care to our sick ones. During the influenza epidemic he cared for forty-five of our people who were stricken with the disease and not one case resulted seriously. In every way he and his assistants have co-operated with us in the care of our sick and I wish to assure them that their services are greatly appreciated. I wish to thank you, Honorable Board of Com - missioners of State Institutions, for your wise counsel and advice, kind treatment and the interest you have taken in our institution and children. You have done much for us during the past biennium and I know you will consider wisely our needs for the future. Respectfully submitted Amy V. Stevens Superintendent. Lincoln, Nebraska, November 30, 1918. General repairs 1,000.0( Traveling expenses 3,500.0( Other maintenance 32.000.0C Furniture and equipment (furnishing and equipping new kitchen ) 1.000.0C Improvements to buildings and grounds (enclosing second story porch in rear of building) 600. (it New building (receiving cottage) 5.000.0C Land 5.000.0C
